Introduction

Magnesium is involved in several physiological processes, including neuromuscular function, enzyme activity, and energy metabolism.  The normal serum magnesium concentration range is approximately 1.5 mg/dL to 2 mg/dL.  Hypermagnesemia and hypomagnesemia require prompt recognition and management to prevent potentially serious complications.

Pathophysiology



The human body contains about 2,000 mEq of magnesium with approximately 99% stored intracellularly or within bone; only 1% is present in the extracellular fluid.



Magnesium homeostasis is maintained through a delicate balance involving several factors.

Bone storage



Approximately 50%-60% of total body magnesium is stored in the bones, which serve as a reservoir for maintaining serum levels.

Renal handling



The kidneys are the primary regulators of magnesium balance.  Unlike most other solutes, the proximal tubule reabsorbs only 10% of filtered magnesium.  The majority (50%-70%) is passively reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb, with most of the remaining magnesium reabsorbed more distally.  Only 3%-5% of filtered magnesium is normally excreted in urine.

Gastrointestinal handling



Dietary sources provide 240-480 mg/day of magnesium, with 30%-40% absorbed primarily in the small intestine.  Absorption can increase to 80% with magnesium deficiency.



Disruptions in any of these processes can lead to hypermagnesemia or hypomagnesemia, which can in turn affect calcium and potassium homeostasis.  Magnesium is essential for the secretion and action of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which regulates calcium levels.  Magnesium also plays an important role in maintaining normal potassium levels (eg, maintaining Na-K-ATPase function, preventing renal potassium wasting).

Hypomagnesemia

Presentation and etiologies



Hypomagnesemia is more common than hypermagnesemia and tends to be more dangerous (ie, greater risk of cardiac arrhythmia).  Symptoms may arise from low magnesium itself, secondary hypocalcemia, or concomitant hypokalemia.  Secondary hypocalcemia is due to PTH suppression from low magnesium (especially <1 mg/dL).  Hypokalemia often exists with hypomagnesemia because of shared causes (eg, diarrhea, diuretics) and magnesium's role in maintaining potassium homeostasis (through its effects on cellular ion transport and renal potassium handling).  Symptoms often reflect a combination of these electrolyte disorders, and include tremors, muscle cramps, tetany, seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and hyperactive deep tendon reflexes (DTRs).



Etiologies include:



  • Gastrointestinal (GI) losses
    • Diarrhea, malabsorption syndromes, short bowel syndrome, and acute pancreatitis (ie, fat saponification as with calcium) can lead to GI magnesium losses.
    • Proton pump inhibitors can alter intestinal magnesium absorption, typically with chronic use (>1 year).
  • Renal losses
    • Medications (eg, loop and thiazide diuretics, aminoglycosides, amphotericin)
    • Alcohol use disorder (eg, tubular dysfunction leads to urinary magnesium wasting)
    • Genetic disorders (eg, Gitelman and Bartter syndromes)
    • Uncontrolled hyperglycemia can lead to urinary magnesium wasting.
    • Hypercalcemia can cause hypomagnesemia by impairing renal magnesium reabsorption.


Inadequate oral intake is an exceedingly rare cause because nearly all foods contain some magnesium, and the required daily intake is only 300-400 mg/day.

Evaluation



A thorough history and physical examination should be performed, focusing on potential causes of magnesium loss.  DTRs should be assessed, as hyperreflexia can be an early sign of hypomagnesemia.  Hypocalcemia and hypokalemia should be identified because they commonly coexist with hypomagnesemia.  An ECG should be obtained, particularly in severe cases, to look for dangerous arrhythmias including ventricular tachycardia and torsades de pointes (

figure 1
); nonspecific changes may include PR prolongation, QRS widening, and QT prolongation.



If the cause of low magnesium is not obvious from the patient's history, measuring urinary magnesium excretion can help distinguish between GI and renal losses.  Options include 24-hour urinary magnesium collection or calculating the fractional excretion of magnesium (FEMg) using a random urine sample:



([Magnesium]urine × [Creatinine]serum / (0.7 × [Magnesium]serum × [Creatinine]urine)



A value of >10-30 mg/day or a FEMg >3%-4% indicate renal wasting.

Management



Treatment of hypomagnesemia involves both acute repletion and addressing the underlying cause.



  • Asymptomatic or mild hypomagnesemia
    • Oral magnesium supplements (eg, magnesium chloride or oxide) are first-line treatment.  If these are not tolerated (eg, diarrhea), intravenous magnesium sulfate may be necessary.
  • Symptomatic or severe hypomagnesemia
    • Administer intravenous magnesium sulfate.
    • Correct associated electrolyte abnormalities (especially calcium and potassium).
  • Chronic management
    • Treat underlying causes.
    • Provide ongoing oral supplementation, if indicated.
    • Perform regular monitoring of serum magnesium levels.


In patients with low magnesium in combination with hypocalcemia and/or hypokalemia, correcting magnesium deficiency is often necessary before calcium and potassium levels can be normalized.  Magnesium repletion restores PTH action and promotes normal potassium handling.

Hypermagnesemia

Presentation and etiologies



Hypermagnesemia is relatively uncommon due to efficient renal excretion but can occur in cases of impaired renal function or massive magnesium intake.  Symptoms are usually not apparent until serum levels exceed 4-5 mg/dL and largely affect neuromuscular and cardiovascular function.  Symptoms include nausea, lethargy, muscle weakness, and diminished or absent DTRs; in severe cases (>12 mg/dL), respiratory depression, quadriplegia, and cardiac collapse may be seen.  Unlike hypomagnesemia, hypermagnesemia does not typically cause significant secondary electrolyte disturbances, although very high levels can occasionally suppress PTH, potentially leading to mild hypocalcemia.



Etiologies include:



  • Impaired renal excretion
    • Acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease can impair renal magnesium clearance.
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, a genetic disorder involving dysregulated calcium handling, can cause mild hypomagnesemia (accompanying hypocalcemia).
  • Massive intake
    • Intravenous administration (eg, preeclampsia treatment) can overwhelm the kidneys' ability to excrete magnesium.
    • Magnesium-containing medications (eg, laxatives, antacids, enemas) can lead to magnesium accumulation, although usually to a lesser extent than from intravenous magnesium.
  • Increased release from cells
    • Conditions causing significant cellular damage (eg, crush injuries, severe burns, tumor lysis syndrome, hemolysis) can release magnesium into the bloodstream.

Evaluation



Assessment includes a detailed history of medication use, particularly magnesium-containing products.  Renal function should be evaluated.  DTRs should be carefully assessed, as their progressive diminishment correlates strongly with the severity of hypermagnesemia and can be an early clinical sign; this test is routinely performed in pregnant patients receiving magnesium therapy for preeclampsia.  An ECG should be obtained to look for changes that can be similar to hypomagnesemia (eg, PR prolongation, QRS widening, QT prolongation), usually seen with magnesium >6 mg/dL; ventricular tachyarrhythmias are not typically seen.

Management



Treatment of hypermagnesemia depends on the severity and presence of symptoms:



  • Mild-to-moderate asymptomatic hypermagnesemia
    • Address underlying cause (eg, discontinue magnesium-containing products).
    • Ensure adequate volume status (eg, intravenous fluids).
  • Symptomatic or severe hypermagnesemia
    • Intravenous calcium for cardiac membrane stabilization.
    • Loop diuretics to promote renal magnesium excretion (avoid in volume depletion).
    • In obstetric patients receiving magnesium for preeclampsia, magnesium therapy should be paused with diminishing DTRs.
    • Hemodialysis in severe cases, typically in renal failure.

Summary



Magnesium disorders can significantly impact neuromuscular and cardiovascular function.  Effective management of these conditions requires a comprehensive understanding of magnesium homeostasis, including gastrointestinal absorption, bone storage, and renal excretion.



Hypomagnesemia is more prevalent and is due to gastrointestinal (eg, diarrhea) or renal losses (eg, diuretics); it often coexists with hypokalemia and hypocalcemia.  Management involves oral or intravenous magnesium repletion, correction of associated electrolyte abnormalities, and addressing underlying causes to prevent recurrence.



Although uncommon, hypermagnesemia can arise from impaired renal excretion, massive intake, or cellular destruction (eg, tumor lysis syndrome).  Treatment ranges from addressing underlying causes in mild cases to intravenous calcium, loop diuretics, and hemodialysis in renal failure.
